results.headline: Coming of Age With Adults Who Haven’t

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Way, Way Back

results.summary_short: In “The Way, Way Back,” two surrogate fathers dominate a 14-year-old boy’s days and fight, implicitly, for his young soul.

results.headline: Smut’s Softer Side: Rakish Pornographer as Loving Parent

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Look of Love

results.summary_short: In “The Look of Love,” Steve Coogan plays Paul Raymond, a British tycoon who built his empire on strip clubs, soft-core pornography and real estate.

results.headline: Unable to Move On, as a Writer or a Lover

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stuck in Love

results.summary_short: “Stuck in Love” focuses on a divorced novelist who nurtures his teenage offspring’s literary aspirations and remains obsessed with his ex-wife.

results.headline: If Thelma and Louise Were Belly Dancers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Just Like a Woman

results.summary_short: In Rachid Bouchareb’s “Just Like a Woman,” Sienna Miller and Golshifteh Farahani take a road trip to flee their bad marriages.

results.headline: A Shaky Camera and a Missing Fetus

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Absence

results.summary_short: In “Absence,” a young woman wakes up to find that she’s no longer pregnant, and she doesn’t know why.

results.headline: Comedic Soul-Searching, Punctuated by Pyrotechnics

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kevin Hart : Let Me Explain

results.summary_short: Kevin Hart’s new stand-up comedy film mines his personal and professional low points, as well as parenthood, for material.

results.headline: Hero Rides Again, With Big Boots to Fill

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lone Ranger

results.summary_short: Gore Verbinski’s reimagining of “The Lone Ranger” tries to give today’s kids their own version of the white-hat western hero with his laconic Indian sidekick.

results.headline: An Ex-Villain Returns as Mr. Sweets

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Despicable Me 2

results.summary_short: With its frantic, Looney Tunes-style madness, “Despicable Me 2” is consistently diverting and so cute you’ll want to pet it.

results.headline: A Stillborn Band’s Rock Is Rediscovered
results.display_title: Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me

results.summary_short: Drew DeNicola and Olivia Mori’s documentary is a homage to the 1970s group Big Star.

results.headline: Oops, Forgot Where I Hid All the Loot

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghanchakkar

results.summary_short: A bank robbery and amnesia are central elements of the Bollywood comedy “Ghanchakkar.”

results.headline: Partying On as the Glitter Ball Whirls

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Secret Disco Revolution

results.summary_short: The interviewees in “The Secret Disco Revolution” seem a bit surprised by the filmmaker’s idea that their music was political.

results.headline: Old Masters, Sweet Mysteries

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Museum Hours

results.summary_short: Filmed in the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna, Jem Cohen’s “Museum Hours” is a contemporary story of cross-cultural friendship.

results.headline: Foot Soldiers in the Battle for a Fair Shake

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gideon's Army

results.summary_short: “Gideon’s Army” centers on public defenders in the South devoted to seeking the best outcome for criminal suspects with minimal resources.

results.headline: Drinking Blood in Broad Daylight

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Byzantium

results.summary_short: “Byzantium,” based on a play by screenwriter Moira Buffini, draws its vampire lore from the Caribbean folk tradition of soucouyant.

results.headline: Undying Passion, Despite a Sex Change

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Laurence Anyways

results.summary_short: In “Laurence Anyways,” a couple endure — off and on — after one confides to the other that he wants to become a woman.

results.headline: Cop Buddies, Packing Extra X Chromosomes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Heat

results.summary_short: “The Heat,” directed by Paul Feig, is a cop-buddy movie, but the buddies are women, Sandra Bullock and Melissa McCarthy.

results.headline: Old Flames Before New Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Some Girl(s)

results.summary_short: “Some Girl(s),” a film adaptation of Neil LaBute’s stage play, follows Adam Brody as he tracks down his former girlfriends.

results.headline: Wilted Spirits in an Abstemious Family

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Petunia

results.summary_short: “Petunia,” starring Christine Lahti, David Rasche and Thora Birch, centers on a therapist couple and their not entirely happy brood.

results.headline: Dizzying Heights, Endless Loops

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I'm So Excited

results.summary_short: Pedro Almodóvar’s “I’m So Excited!” includes many silly bits and a nod to Hitchcock’s “Vertigo.”

results.headline: Have a Nice Visit; Come Save Us Again

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of White House Down

results.summary_short: Channing Tatum rescues the president (Jamie Foxx) and the nation in the action-adventure “White House Down.”
